												Your popularity...*Dramatic pause*IS RISING!Update:Wow, I honestly never imagined that this joke would reach the lengths it did. I suppose this justifies an actual review.Welcome to Stronghold Crusader, a game I picked up at a whim when I was 12 (actually have about 1,000 hours clocked in the disc version of the game; I was sheltered from Steam for a long time). I had, at the time, no idea what the game was about, I just knew that I was a huge medieval era fan and decided the game looked pretty cool. Trust me though, no matter of sweet, sweet disc cover could have prepared me for the fungasm that was Stronghold Crusader. Lets move on to an actual review now.Stronghold Crusader is an RTS (real-time strategy) game based on the First, Second, and Third Crusade, not to mention the conflicts within Crusader states. As with all RTS', this means that you will have control of armies, workers, not to mention fortification and building construction in an attempt to outwit your opponent and kill their king. However, Stronghold does this better than even most current-generation RTS', in my opinion, including games like Starcraft 2. It's hard for me to come up with a "pros and cons" list, because for me, this game doesn't have any cons; difficulty is to be expected as you progress in time spent in-game. Let me spend a little time bulleting what is so attractive about this game.-There is a multitude of units. You've got your various siege equipment (battering rams, catapults, trebuchets, you name it), melee units with their own unique advantages, ranged units similarly, various traps, MOATS (that's right nerdy kid who loves castles, moats), and chances are you will end up using every single one of these characters at some point during the game; which leads to my next point.-No two games are alike. Before anyone corrects me, I'm aware that there are (always have been) certain strategies to try and end games quickly; slave rushing; mercenary armies in early game, etc. That being said, these strategies are not always reliable and will leave you resourceless. The fact is that you are probably going to need a different strategy for each game you play, ESPECIALLY in multiplayer.-The game itself is rich in history, which I personally find fascinating. The single player campaign will have you drilling your way through multiple missions; these missions are based off the real accounts of the First, Second, and Third Crusades, as well as the intergroup struggles that grew in that time. You will command armies in historic battles like the Siege of Jerusalem, Heraclea, and Krak des Chevaliers. All this is accompanied by what I find to be a stellar set of voice actors and most likely the best squire a king could ever ask for creates an almost life-like representation of the era. You know what, the squire gets his own bullet.-The squire; this awesome individual is your in-game guide/cheerleader/father-figure. If you play the game, you WILL learn to love him. The squire is a non-physical character who informs you of how you are doing, whether you are under attack, or if you are out of resources. He will sit and shout in your ear "WOOD NEEDED" or "THE GRANARY STOCKS ARE FULL, M'LORD." -Resource management. While not really a new feature to RTS', the resource management in this game will force you to think steps ahead of your opponent, or suffer the consequences; every resource is expendable. "Not enough stone to build your walls? Buy some from the trade post for gold, or trade your other resources to get that precious stone. Beware, though, trade too much of one resource and it may dry up and your stocks will quickly be depleted, which means you are screwed when it comes to anything that requires that resource.-Multiplayer. This is where 90% of my horus playing this game went. I could sit here and rant onward about all of my games where I had almost lost, but like the underdog of the story, I prevailed!However, I won't; as a matter of fact, I will make this really simple: take every bulletpoint I've created, and imagine what it'd be like to face another person. The campaign missions may not necessarily be the most difficult, but the multiplayer is where I am convinced Army strategists should be trained for real-life duty. How you act in a game, every move you make, every resource you spend/use, will affect the outcome and decide whether you are truly the king of the land, or whether you are a lonely peasant, not fit to lick the boot of your opponent.TL;DR:Despite not being the most "relevant" entry in the RTS genre, Stronghold Crusader still manages to remain an idol to be followed for other RTS games. If you are truly skipping my beautifully composed points above, just know that the game is wonderful. For the price it's listed at now, I would say you are criminally insane to not buy it."Do you recommend this game?" Steam asks.My response? "Of course, m'lord!"

												There's nothing much like building a huge empire castle with seemingly undefetable defenses, and than it all falls apart just because your friend was one step ahead of you the whole time building his army of tens of thousands of men to take down your castle. Stronghold Crusader HD delivers this on every level. This game and I go way back, to 2006, My brother chose this game as a game that he wanted to buy from Target. At first I hated this game, mostly because I didn't try it. After I did try it one rainy day I fell in love with it. It does take a little bit to learn everything, but once you do it is one of the most addicting and fact paced Stragety games of all time!PROS:+ Simple but nice graphics: Sure they aren't amazing, but it has a disctinct art style that does help make you feel more a part of that world.+ Amazing strategic gameplay, It lures you in by seeming to be simple with a decent+The voice acting AWFUL, but it is the kind of awful that you and your friends can have a good hearty laugh at, and of course the quotes with the "voice actors" deliver really helps make this game feel all its own and have it's entirely own feeling to it.+ Fun Characters: the characters have their own personalities, and while some are addmitedly one note (the pig is fat GET IT!?) It adds more that subtracts from the experiance.+Great Map Selection (Some very basic ones and some really interesting ones, over 20! (Over 100 if you look at just the skirmish ones [Although I do belive they are exclusive to skirmish which I would like to see changed and probally there is a way to do it manually] And of coruse, you can make your own.)+ A ton of Gameplay types. There is, Custom Map Maker, 4 (or 4+) Campaigns, 3 (Including the Extreme Expansion) Trials (Which are linked matches between you and a bot, there are 50 on the original one. 30 on the Warchest one and 20 on the Extreme Trails) But, there is a major problem with the extreme trials (as of 12/30/13) it starts you at the final one for some reason) and of coruse Skirmish Mode (You can play what map you want with either friends, or solo and choose teams and such. oh and one more thing, Castle Sim Mode is just like Skirmish Mode, but without the batltes. ))+Fantastic Music! It is not only atmospheric but can also be catchy as hell and sounds natural helping the imersion of the game by a boatload! The game even changes music depending on the situation you are in, are you getting bombarded by a bunch of spear men? Then the game will switch to an intense battle song and fade out as soon as you (hopefull) defeat the spearmen. +The netcode is HIGHLY improoved in my experiances to the original, back in the original every game would be pleagued by the infamous "Connection lost, sending current game state" message, however  if I do ever encounter it in this version it dissapears in a split second!+This version is compatable with the original! So, if your friends computer can't handle the brand new resolution just install the CD version and you can play with the HD version (with GameRanger of course!) and this helps blend the line between the Steam players and the CD Players. The same can not be said about AOE2 HD or RON:EXE.+The game runs great on all types of hardware, from my ancient (Basically) 2010 Notebook to my modern computer (which I am writing this review with) and even my Aspire R14, the game runs without a hitch and surprisingly has minimal compatibility glitches [Not including the ones that were there]CONS:+Troops sometimes ignore orders, or take a while to do them. Sometimes you will tell it to do something and they will just wonder off which gets annoying especially in the heat of battle.+It's sometimes hard to see close into your castle with the brand new resolution, it would be nice if you could zoom into the map even further.+Some AI share the same animations (most notably, The Rat and the Wolf if you have them on your team.+Some Animation's are choppy (The blacksmith preview goes at about 20 frames)+When you zoom out all the way the FPS halves.+The AI is awful. They rarley (if ever) change up their attacks and do the same thing over and over again. Some AI is over protective making invading their castle a hastle [hahaha! GET IT!] to a point where I just save the game, quit, and never return to that saved game. +Balancing Issues: Little problems that they are you may have to (atleast in multiplayer) turn on the No Rush timer as to not allow people to bombard your castle with Assassins which are not only fast, invisible (unless nearing your men), and strong, but they also have a surprisingly large health bar which makes killing them annoying as they mow down even your strongest men and take out your king (how you loose) without a problem as early as the first few minutes. [They fixed this in the 2nd Game however that is a whole different can of worms.]+No proper Steamworks Multiplayer support, you must download a game client like GameRanger (which isn't bad, just inconvenient] +Awful expansion. Stronghold Crusader HD Extreme is the included expansion and adds some fantastic stuff [Maps, campaigns, 8 new AI Characters] but sadly starts to support castle hiding where you hide everyone inside your castle and let you generate stuff (yes this expansion adds a Mana styled magic bar that lets you create stuff and destroy your enemies castle with flying rocks that you spawn) which sounds badass. However, it throws all balancing and fairness out the window. Anyone can click on the rocks and click on the enemy castle to demolish it and make it ripe for the conquest, however what Stronghold Crusader HD (The base game) strives on is the ability to conquest the castle using your men that you build up which makes it imsenly more satisfying and more fair to put it bluntly.+Glitches. The main one that I am talking about is when you launch SC:HD Extreme for the first time and you go to the skirmish mission you get the due honor of skipping directly to the last level for no apparent reason, effectivly making the previous 20 or so missions useless. Overall:Even in the ripe year of 2016 Stronghold Crusader HD has surprisingly aged well. The problems (Some miniscule others annoying) really don't distract from the overall experiance as much as one may think. The PROS FAR outweigh the CONS in this situation and makes Stronghold Crusader HD (even with the Flawed Extreme expansion) a great time that is easily worth the 9.99 asking price. And even if you don't feel confortable about paying that much it goes on sale for down to 5 dollars sometimes so keep an eye out because I assure you, its a game that you will need to see to believe. [In a good way]If you enjoyed this review you should check out my fellow reviewers at  Completing the Backlog Edit: And hey this game has some great uses for cows...

This is a long review, so if you want a brief summary of why I recommend Stronghold Crusader skip to Results and read from there.Firefly Studies strikes again with the best Stronghold game in the series. Stronghold Crusader is a brilliant game that mixes Castle Simulation with RTS combat, and resource management. Story:As the title depicts Stronghold Crusader takes place in the Crusades. You play through the Asia minor, The Middle East, as Europeans and Arabians alike. The story takes place across four campaigns where you start your journey as Emporer Alexus of the Turkish Army commands you to take ahold of Asia Minor. You spread European influence across the land, but it is short lived as the Salidan rises to power and destroys the settlements of the Europeans and claims back the lands. Unfortunately for him the crusades were not over, and the Germanic armies arrive deploying castles across Asia minor as they claim lay to the holy lands. Stronghold Crusader takes place across the first to third crusades and then creates an alternate reality that is the post-crusade wars that pit you against your worst nightmare: The Rat, The Snake, The Pig, and The Wolf. Campaign:Stronghold Crusader has four campaigns which teach you how to play the game from the basics to the most advanced.The Call to ArmsCall to Arms offers five basic missions which although simple are in fact challenging in their own rights. The first mission encompasses basic castle siege, the second basic defense, the third resource management, the fourth resource massing, and the final one a more complicated castle siege. This campaign is a great way to start into the Stronghold Series as it introduces the elements of gameplay in an interesting way that keeps you entertained. Typical tutorials are rather uninteresting, but Call to Arms changes that by providing dynamic missions that introduce the game with diverse scenarios. Saladin’s ConquestAfter the conquest of Call to Arms you pick up the campaign as Salidan who is retaking the land stolen by the Europeans. All the missions in Salidan’s Conquest are sieges; these involve taking castles from the enemy. All of Salidans missions are rather simple, yet offer diversity in how you conquer your foe. You are limited on units and must use unique units to push through the enemy defenses. The Kings CrusadeAfter the Salidan has kicked out most of Europe the quest continues as the third crusade picks up and its up to the Europeans to hold off their fortresses from the Salidans onslaughts. The Kings Crusade mostly focuses on castle building and defense, similar to Mission 4 of The Call to Arms. Each level provides new features which give you a better mechanism to defend you castle and equip you against an ever stronger foe until you eventually must siege castle and rebuild it from the ground up. Crusader StatesThe campaign begins after the third crusade and is a fictitious rendition of what we expected after the Third Crusade ended. You play in the Middle East as lord’s squalor over various lands and it is up to you to defeat your foes. Your mission through the Middle East pits you against the foes of the past: The Rat, The Snake, The Pig, and The Wolf. The further you get into the campaign the more enemies you get pit against. Gameplay:Stronghold Crusader is noted as being the best Stronghold game; it took what was good from the original and expanded upon it beautifully. Stronghold Crusader is a castle simulation game, where you manage a castle politically, economically, and sociologically. You must maintain various food types, keep your people happy, while simultaneously ripping them dry for every penny they have. You need to build a well-oiled machine, but unlike most strategy games Stronghold has many resources. To build units you must obtain gold, you must build their weapons, you must provide peasant, you must feed them with various food stocks, and you must obtain the resources required to build those weapons. For all of this to occur you must keep peasants within your castle by making sure they are happy, once they start to leave your castle will crumble from within before your enemies even hit your walls. Stronghold Crusader takes that and incorporates mercenaries, units which cost gold and require less work to obtain. Of course they cost almost triple that of a non-hired unit, but offer quick turn-around. Not only did they add mercenaries, but they included Skirmishes with AI, which allow you to play the game without playing the campaign. The AI is rather intelligent and will keep you on your toes, and not only that but the maps are designed to require intense combat. This game will make you fight over limited agrarian land and low wood stocks. Hints:>When you start a map drop the gamespeed to 20, this gives you loads of time to set yourself up before the match really begins.>When playing the crusader states the game gives you sometimes up to 7.5k gold, if you drop the game-speed to 20 and place a market you can buy Maces and Leather Armor. Then quickly build an army of Macemen to take out your foes before the match can even begin. This does not work on all missions, but certainly helps.>Bread is the easiest food to build-up. If you are trying to optimize limited farmland use wheat as its easy to mass. Results:Stronghold Crusader is the best castle simulation game out there right now. It offers the joy of castle simulation with the intensities of combat. I would recommend this game to anyone who is thinking about taking part in the Stronghold Series, it’s a great place to start as it will pull you right in. 												A lot of sequels strike out in new directions, and end up falling flat for their trouble. Sometimes they get too far away from what made the original great, and other times they find a way to ruin that original appeal. The other side of the coin is that just giving players more of the original risks making the series stale. This is the approach that Stronghold Crusader took in the wake of Stronghold's success, but the sheer volume of content more than makes up for the lack of innovation.Just as you did in Stronghold, Crusader challenges you to erect and manage castles throughout a variety of scenarios and skirmishes. Once your keep and granary are placed, it's up to you to site farms, mills, workshops, and homes to keep your people safe and happy. So long as you remain a popular ruler more people will come serve at your castle, but more people means a greater drain on your resources. In the midst of balancing these two factors you'll need to raise walls and armies to fend off invaders seeking your crown.The familiar moors of England have given way to the marauding Moors of the holy land for this outing. There are a few big changes to be aware of, most notably the desert maps. Gone are the rolling fields of the first game, instead leaving you with small oases to supply your essential farms and woodcutters. A mercenary post allows you to recruit new Arabian units, everything from armored swordsmen to wall-scaling assassins. There's even a rudimentary diplomacy system, allowing you to form alliances and request resources.Stronghold Crusader features four historical campaigns, focusing on different parts of the Crusades. Each campaign is five scenarios long and features a gentle learning curve that provides a fair challenge by the end. There's little story to be found here in contrast with Stronghold's tale of political maneuvering, just some blurbs about historical relevance. The real meat of the game is the Crusader mode, a campaign of up to 50 battles against AI opponents. Right from the get-go you can access all the buildings and options the game has to offer in pursuit of conquest, building your perfect citadel and laying siege to nearby enemies. The strategy of castle-to-castle warfare takes a little getting used to after the easy pace of the campaigns, but it's thrilling to launch pitched battles and deploy siege engines to topple your foes.There's not a lot of innovation to be found here over the original Stronghold, but there really doesn't need to be. Crusader instead gives you plenty more to see and do, especially on the military side. The graphics are a bit improved, with sharper structures and cleaner animations, and the sounds of both peace and battle are just as immersive as before. Honestly, I consider this the superior game just due to the depth of content and the little additions to the proven formula. If you're looking for endless conquest and sieges, this is the Stronghold title you want.

												Stronghold: Crusader is an RTS (real time strategy) game based in the Middle East during the Crusades, namely mainly in the third. Some parts of the game, however, take place before that. It's a kind of extension of the game Stronghold, which Crusader in many aspects resembles, but Stronghold is set in medieval England.Stronghold: Crusader is Stronghold enriched with new mechanics, the most famous of these is the Skirmish mode, the heart of the game. It is a mode in which each player or computer opponent has one base on a map and they must develop, market, prosper and build castles and defense. Since all players are on one map, they can interact with each other, whether it's positively or negatively. Allies can trade with each other, defend each other and attack together. The game goal is most of the time to kill all the enemy Lords and not die in the process. The game balances the economy and the war very well. The player must develop their economy through taxes, food rations, trade and so on. They must seek to balance their popularity to not become unpopular, because in that case people will begin to leave the castle and it will severely impede the player's progress. If the player has a good economy, they can take up making a great army, which is usually quite costly. This is the way the game balances the economy and the war, and I like it. You should think about your tactics and castle management a bit and not just rush into war straight away - otherwise you go to your knees, whether you like it or not.The main objectives of the game itself are the 2 Skirmish trails. They consist of a number of consecutive Skirmishes. In each mission the player has certain enemies, sometimes allies, a set map and everyone's position on it, and a set amount of money and resources. There are 16 PC enemies altogether and about 80 maps (citation needed), so with such diversity there is also an option to play your own game, where the player chooses the map, their allies and adversaries as well as everyone's money and resources. Computer opponents are also quite diverse: 6 Arab and 10 Crusader leaders, each of whom has different castles, different tactics, different personalities, and there's a lot to the game to keep you interested long enough.In addition to Skirmish trails, one can play historical campaigns. They're based on specific historical periods and events during the Crusades. They are there to teach the player the game. The first campaign teaches the fundamentals of the economy, defense and siege. The second campaign teaches the player how to use unique Arab units. In the third campaign the player learns to defend against them, and the fourth campaign is already full-on Skirmish mode. In the first three campaigns the player doesn't have the Skirmish mode freedom because they either defend against attacks at certain intervals, while trying to achieve a set goal (Defend Antioch! Gather 300 loaves of bread!, and the like), while they often don't have access to all buildings - or they get a certain number of soldiers with which to conquer a city. This is exactly why a lot of people find these campaigns boring, tedious and difficult. In a sense they are right. These campaigns are fine, but cumbersome unlike the rest of the game. The game also includes a mode of free castle building without enemies, map editor and LAN multiplayer for 8 players.Crusader Extreme added a bar of (super)powers, which fills up slowly and over time unlocks the abilities for your use - such as a rain of arrows or rocks on a specific place on the map. It also added military outposts - buildings that relatively slowly generate troops for free. This allows all PC adversaries to be stronger than normal - for example the Rat, the weakest adversary, suddenly gets a huge army of swordsmen, pikemen, horse archers and seven catapults - and they're coming for you!Overall, I think that Stronghold: Crusader is an excellent game. Fun and fast paced with minor weak points and bugs, which can be overlooked. 9/10PS: The Steam version doesn't cooperate with Steam firefly fix pls

												Looking for a good RTS? Look no Further.This game is the pinnacle of quality for the Stronghold series. The first game lacks the depth that Crusader has, but is still very good. Problem is that every game after this one, in the Stronghold series, just doesn't measure up. This game has a perfect blend of complexity and simplicity.The game isn't so complicated that its hard to pick up or understand, but not so simple that there is a lack of depth.Likewise the play of the game is balanced between economics/resources management and Military strategy. In some other RTS games it is absolutely true that whoever can rush their economy the fastest is the victor, and I would say that is not the case for this game. Speed is of course an important factor, but unless one player is particularly slow in comparision to the other, speed will not be the deciding factor. The ability you have for using your economy to maximize your military potential through any number of means, as well as your ability to strategically use your troops/resources to take advantage of your opponent's weaknesses are the most important factors.However, understanding your map placement while using this in your overall strategy, and your ability to build/defend your castle are extremely important. A player near less resources with a weaker economy can play more defensively, defeat an opponent's army who lays siege, and then counter attack before the opponent can recover from the losses to pull a victory. Or in the same scenario, the player in a weak spot can harass with the goal to destroy their opponent's economy, thus crippling them, then pressing the advantage. The ways a game can be played and won are vast.Multiplayer is where this depth of gameplay becomes most visible, but due to the direct IP connect multiplayer set up it is easiest to just use a service with lobbies to set up games with randoms. I recommend Game Ranger. The community isn't huge, but is still large enough that it isn't hard to find someone online to play with.From my perspective, this is the greatest RTS of all time.Keeping my personal bias aside, this game is very good, especially for it's time.I believe it is an under appreciated title worth picking up for it's price.TL;DR : Graphics are okay, not confusing or hard to look at, but not stunning due to their age.Gameplay is not without it's flaws, but it is in depth and the application of strategy, awareness, and quick thinking are key. Making use of European and/or Arabic units is also an important element.Multiplayer is fun and much more in depth than playing with bots, but its better to use an external program for matchmakingModes; there are a few to choose from, Multiplayer, custom game mode, there is custom map making which can be shared with other players in multiplayer, Single player has two crusader trails which set you up against bots in specific set ups, and a historical single player mode where you defend real crusader castles like Kerak de Chevaliers.Sounds/Soundtrack nothing I would write home about, but its not hard to listen to either.Should you read this review, and then decide to buy this game and thenwant to get in on multiplayer, feel free to add me.

												My first strategy-type game I have ever played in my childhood. This is where my thirst and hunger for winning started. This may not be for people that are playing a game and evaluating it from a graphical side. It is 2002 game, so.. In my opinion it is pretty strategic and fun to play.My first time that I had to play this game was horrible, because I had absolutelly no logic (Yes, you need to have brain to play this game. This is not just building and done). What I was doing back then just building beautiful buildings, such as church and etc. I didn't know what I was doing. So, when I grew up, I got into this game out of nostalgia. I understood what I was doing at that time, and it was lmao to remember what I was doing back there... xDSo, as I said, this game needs logic, because you are not going to survive and win by doing random ♥♥♥♥. You start up in different locations of the map with your opponents and you the point is to build your castle, make troops and protect yourself and slaughter them. But the most logical part of the game, is management of resources. Gold, stone, wood, food, iron. Nothing complicated. The food is the most essential resource for surviving obviously. Without it, people will leave your castle and you have nothing... So after you have dispatched resource income in appriopriate way and value, you have to build up you castle (That's my favourite part, because you can build in any way you want) and protect it, because everything is risky. They can target your resource income building, which can leave you empty and put you at a disadvantage. Thinking through stuff, and protecting everything is the key. After building up stage, some obviously will choose to attack, and some of them will have to defend. Defending is the most fun part, because after you dispatched your troops at appropriate locatons of defense (such as towers) for protection, it is so satisfying to see how strong is your defense, and after that you can find your weakness. Then, it is up to you, you build up your army, you slaughter, you win. That's all. Also there are campaign and other modes which can give a little bit of a challenge against other opponents. Some stages will be hard, and will give you a location with disadvantages, but it is up to you how you will build up, survive, destroy and win.That I think is everything to this game. I recommend it for players that are interested in strategic. (Bu I am guessing there are people who have started their journey from this one and what I mean is that they already tried it).

												Imagine a real-time, fast-paced strategy game where you enter the Holy Lands following an unforgiving trail of fifty crusaders – each more difficult than the last; each with different enemies, different resources, different allies and different economies. You discover and master the art of defending and storming castles – planning your every move carefully while controlling armies of men, horses, portable-shields, catapults and more in the hundreds. Now, realize that the game in question, Stronghold Crusader, was released twelve years ago and that a succeeder is inbound Q4 2014.In comparison to the original Stronghold, Firefly Studios significantly altered the dynamics of Stronghold Crusader in an attempt to increase the game speed – which unforgivably means the first few minutes of each mission are crucial. The changes includes the addition of a range of Arabian mercenary units, where especially assassins, fire throwers and horse archers introduces a range of new opportunities upon both defending your own castle and conquering others. The traditional military units are still more powerful however, but takes significantly longer to recruit due to the extensive production line. The player must thus analyze the enemies and starting resources swiftly – the sooner the production line can be started, the better. Similar, if the enemies appear weak during the early stages, a quick and silent attack gently delivered by assassins might be preferred.One aspect is to defend your castle and attack enemies, a whole other layer of gameplay, which appears subtle at first glance, is the actual castle management. Stronghold Crusader introduces a range of buildings and techniques which allows the player to generate more money, extra powerful men or a harder working population, to name a few. Increasing your population’s happiness through religion or ale allows for higher taxes, crowding and even food shortages. Similar, increasing the amount of bad things (i.e. gallows, dunking tools or cesspits) in your castle makes your population work faster and thus generate a faster and more efficient money flow.Securing a food chain is even more important than it was in the original Stronghold due to the deserted and rocky terrain which greatly limits the amount of fertile areas. These areas are therefore both interesting and important strategic points; take out an enemy’s food supply and you force him out of his castle. The gameplay thus consists of both castle management, fighting and survival throughout 50 crusades, four chapters of historically inspired missions and an extra 30 crusades introduced after the original release – in total well above 40 hours of campaign gameplay, excluding later free- and custom-play.The RTS-genre has undeniably advanced significantly since the release of Stronghold Crusader on several fronts; including, but not limited to, the graphics (though, admittedly, the old graphics are charming), the audio, the interfaces and the AI. Especially the latter is easily noticeable if you have played any modern RTS-game – the AI in Stronghold Crusader is easily tricked, and once a player reaches a certain point in the map, winning ultimately becomes a matter of time due to the superior human player and the seemingly flat difficulty-level of the AIs. Instead, the game relies on quantity and starting perks such as six AIs with 20.000 gold each versus the player with only 3.000 gold. That said then the game unfortunately suffers from a range of bugs and glitches, which unavoidably results in quite some micromanagement of the player’s troops to ensure they indeed are doing the assigned task accordingly. The path-finding system has a tendency to chose some strange routes, and can, on rare occasions, end up getting your men stuck. Though, remembering the age of the game then these issues are minor and certainly not game breaking – merely frustrating due to the higher focus on micromanagement.The freedom in terms of building and designing your castle is intriguing and very unique compared to other RTS-games. Similar, the actual gameplay is extremely simple and straightforward, but due to the many layers of extra options and techniques during both fighting and castle management, the gameplay is yet challenging – and most importantly, fun. Ignoring the minor bugs and glitches, Stronghold Crusader is a solid game for any RTS-fan, and a great option for those who wishes to enter the genre!

												What's that? No 3D-graphics? Well, guess what... It doesn't need that to be good!Here you are, starting only with some wood, stone and gold. You build - you recruit - you fight - you win (?). It's a simple concept and a lot of strategy games follow this direction. In fact, Stronghold Crusader isn't really complex, so the first sight might give you the impression of a boring city simulator... For me, there's something wonderful about this simplicity.The goal is to be the very best like no one ever was. Kill the enemy's king and get your well-earned peace while you defend your own crown-wearing buddy. Of course they won't invite you into their castle, so you have to invite yourself. In order to blast away their walls and towers, there are different ways, like hammering every single brick off the wall or dig a tunnel underneath it. They won't like you to be that rude, so they put archers on towers to keep your men away and you'll have to get rid of them first somehow! Either you ruin the towers with catapults or invade with own archers and fight back.This isn't what makes Stronghold Crusader so enjoyable. The true entertainment is the possibility to be a rotten ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to them! Every inhabitant of the castle is a free-walking NPC which can be killed too. It is incredibly annoying when your enemy has posted some archers beneath your farms and keeps killing your farmers. Not only is it very time consuming to fight off those archers, but it's also very stressful for the castle's economy. Every killed farmer means a lost delivery of food, and without food your people will get very angry. Your people start to leave your castle when you keep being such a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and soon you will only have three peasants left.If this is still too weak for you, you can step it up and use dirty tricks to wreck'em! If you manage to lit an enemy's building on fire, it will spread out drasticly, burning down every house 'n' human. This could lead to a total destruction of the castle, making them to start from the beginning. Fire is a great element of the game, because it can turn a lost-believed battle into a success.Otherwise I'd say it's a classic RTS. Build, fight and succeed. There are  singleplayer campaigns, but the true enjoyment is the multiplayer with friends, because of the nasty actions possible. Sadly you'll have to fiddle around with IPs and networks in order to connect to each other. Because this game doesn't require alot performance, the connection is always stable (at least for me it always was) and free of laggs. All I can say is that I've played this game for whole days years ago and I still enjoy this piece. The graphics may look very old and bad, but I think it only adds to the charisma the game shows.

												[10 unique and valuable pro tips for beating crusader extreme below]As someone who was addicted to strategy games around the time the original crusader game came out, I would heavily recommend this to people who either like age of empires, who would like to relive those days and to those people who like challenges. The game includes Crusader Extreme HD, with missions 'so difficult' (the first 14 missions took me 1-3 hours each, excluding some start-over missions because i failed) that you need to resort to a very defensive guerilla/ninja playing style to succeed. there's missions where u have to defeat more than 7 opponents on a single map, all by yourself. And everyone starts with the same resources. After some restarted missions and succeeding (im about halfway now i guess, at mission 14) i found out a strategy that works out for 90% of the missions. If you want to figure this out yourself do not read on, i will not mention anything new. but for those who quit out of frustration heres how you can do it:1. some missions involve defeating multiple opponents of which some are very closeby, even withing arrow range of your castle (you dont want that). use up all you money to build knights and send them in to kill the enemies close to you. in some missions, its possible to kill enemy lords before they have even built their castle.2. NEVER forget to build a market in the beginning. not all maps offer all resource types within range or within castle building range, which means e.g. if theres only quarry near the keep, you will have to put as any quarry miines there as possible and sell some of it to buy stone/wood. 3. always start off building 3 more stockpile spaces (free), a market, 2-4 hovels depending on how much starting resources u have, and a combination of 5, 10 or 15 'good things' and a church (or 2, if u can),  and either a mercenary post or barracks + armory. buying weapons to recruit non-mercenary troops is usually cheaper. mercenary post recommended when u have a lot of starting money.4. build a wall ASAP around your keep with enough space to put in all your buildings needed to recruit ttroops and keep the economy going. set mercenary slaves or regular troops like spearman and archers at work to dig a moat on the inner side of the wall, then build another wall that will actually function as your wall. the first wall is just to protect them from harm while digging. if youre skilled at timing things and monitoring progress, you won't need to but if you have plenty of starting cash in some missions then this is a safe method. 5. do not forget to build stairs at your walls. because it is not possible to build when enemies are close and then your guys wont be able to man the walls/towers you built.6. if you build a keep, always build a bridge at it right away.7. save up the rock volley to slowly kill off enemytroop spawn posts during missions. do not use it up for anything else unless you really really need it because you would lose your lord otherwise or enemy is about to breach walls. 8. enemy knights are the biggest problem when they attack early in the game. therefore, just buy leather armour and crossbows and build crossbow archers or when low on cash u will need sligshot mercs who have strengths in great numbers.9. last but very important tip: if u wanna destroy an enemy castle, bring plenty of archers. like 50+ . and put them in a place where they can hit the enemies campfire where the peasants gather. set attack location instead of directly clicking a peasant cuz they will stop attacking when all peasants are down and hit other targets instead. this prevents them from building new troops while u are attacking, which was often the reason i lost all my troops cuz the enemy started building knights superfast and in the end i didnt have enough troops to get on top of the keep and kill the leader.10. Try to build a perimiter wall ALL AROUND buildings that involve a production chain. if it's not possible, put a big waterpot near valuable locations and station some archers that can easily kill off slaves who want to lit up your mines for example.i could give more tips, but these things i found out and used helped me through the first 14 missions fairly easy. you should figure the rest out for yourself through trial and error

												I had played this years ago and had hit a wall IIRC, where one of the levels I kept losing to and gave up.  So it can be challenging.It can also be a little grindy if you haven't gone through the tutorial (me) and figured out all the different units and maybe some more combined arms strategy.  ==It gets very grindy.==Basically this is Age of Empires or others from that RTS genre and timeframe, but this emphasizes the happiness mechanic by allowing bribing or taxing the people and feeding or starving them, along with other buildings that might affect happiness or fear and productivity.  Of couse once you understand the new mechanic, it's not too interesting - it translates into more buttons to push and wanting some manager to handle all that - but this is an old game.  They hadn't invented managers yet.Note: A key difference from Age of Empires is that in Stronghold, if you have enough resources for <whatever>, purchasing that creates it _instantaneously_.  There's no wait for units to churn out or buildings to build - they are there the moment you click the build button.I'm on the 6th or so level in the campain, and I have yet to build a decent "castle-looking" castle.  It all becomes more like a tower defense game in that regard.Voice acting is excellent, though not too varied.  There's some nice cuteness there I really like the archers and the when the knight complains if you ask him to walk all over the continent!  Hahaha :)ALSO nice surprise was the inclusion of a Stronghold Crusader "Extreme" add-on, which I'd never heard of until I downloaded the game.  It's apparently a set of new scenarios.

												Stronghold Crusader had the best gameplay in the entire series, but the graphics were getting a little bit outdated after a decade. This HD re-release makes it look good enough to last another decade. Don't expect fancy 3D graphics, this is old-school isometric 2.5D.The gameplay is solid. There are tutorials to teach you the basics and there are two "crusader trails" with about 50 missions each to give you a lot of different scenarios to play through. There are also campaigns with a story to them. You play as a lord in the time of the crusades. You start with a small manor and a hand full of troops and there are enemies who want you dead. Build farms to grow food to keep your population alive. Gather resources such as wood, stone and metal. Build up a castle wall-by-wall according to your own design. Put down towers of different shapes and sizes: small tall towers to give your archers extra range, and big lower towers on which you can mount siege weapons. Have your population craft weapons to train soldiers or hire mercenaries with gold. Then try to invade your enemies' castles. Build catapults to destroy their walls, or use siege ladders to get your archers on their walls to turn their safe castle into a slaughterhouse. Beware of hidden traps like spike pits and burning oil.Skirmish mode allows you to pick from a few dozen maps, some balanced and some unbalanced. Want to play 4 vs 4 on a balanced map? Want a real challenge, then pick an unbalanced map and stack the odds against you. The AI does not have traditional difficulty levels, but there are a number of AI personalities that have their own strategy. Fighting against the Caliph means you have to be prepared dirty tricks like waves of slaves trying to burn down your farms, and fire arrow archers trying to set the ground on fire when you try to take his castle. King Richard attacks with honor and superior force using siege weapons and heavily armored units. The Sultan is a dreamer who focuses more on building an economy than training a superior army. The Snake thows large numbers of archers and spearmen at you, favoring quantity over quality.

												When I purchased Stronghold HD, Stronghold Crusader HD came bundled with it and since I loved the original (my review of Stronghold HD can be found here), I had high hopes of it. The original was a great and unique combination of a castle/city builder and siege-simulator and this game is no different, basically the same game all over again, except that it's not that great anymore. The game feels like an expansion to the original game and not a sequel, mostly because it uses shamelessly everything from Stronghold HD, which wouldn't necessarily be a problem, but it remains inferior to the original in almost every aspect. The milieu is the (not so) vast deserts of the Middle East in the Holy Land mostly during the Third Crusade. The so called historical campaigns are separated from each other and seem rather inconsistent, so there's hardly a plot which makes the single player game unsatisfying. The skirmish missions are even less entertaining, so those don't help the game either. There's also an expansion called Stronghold Crusader Extreme HD, which is super disappointing and all it does that it allows the player to set custom games (which we can do in the main game as well) under extreme conditions and fight multiple opponents at the same time who tend to start with more resources than us... I managed to beat 2 at the same time, but it was a very poor experience, reminding me of old-school 'real-time strategy' games that functioned like meat grinders, where you train more and more troops and just unleash them on your enemies. Some 'strategy'...The main difference between the original game and this one is mainly the environment: instead of the beautiful English forestry, we get to play in deserts. It makes the game harder because now anything can catch fire and that introduces the only (!) new building (the other new one is basically a tent): the well. Yes, we can only put out the randomly appearing fires using wells (or instead of several small ones just one big well). Of course the wells also require workforce, so it is vital to have a few extra peasants. Naturally wells can't prevent the occurrence of fires, so the building on fire is going to take damage and if it's the armoury full of weapons... well, we're in trouble. The other factor is the oasis, which is the only suitable area we can build food production buildings on and needless to say, their size is quite limited. At least the oasis makes the game harder in a good way (requiring careful planning), as opposed to the random fire occurrences.In a few missions we can play the Muslim side, but these are commando missions (can't train units, have to make do with the given ones) only, so we can forget about larger sieges, the main strength of Stronghold. Of course there is sense in the Muslims having no buildings: they should look different than the ones the crusaders have... By the way the crusaders do have Middle-Eastern looking buildings which is a bit strange, but at this point it's really just one of the smaller problems.There are Arabian soldiers, mercenaries we can hire from the previously mentioned tents, for gold (instead of resources). This is an interesting formula as it can speed up the process of training quite a bit, but again, it can turn the game into grindfests at the expense of sieges. The new soldiers are fun (the slingers are fast and cheap but are weak and can attack at short range, the horse archers have great range and are very fast, but expensive and not as accurate as the normal archers), but they are mostly reused versions of the already existing units with readjusted strengths, except slaves (super cheap and weak units who can set buildings on fire) and the assassins (can climb walls and open castle gates). The assassin does have potential and can make a siege more interesting and a bit easier for the attacker. There's also a new fire ballista, a perfect tool for decimating defending archers on towers and it's also a welcome addtion to the attacking side.Some issues that were in the original are also present here: the transparency of the buildings is still a problem when rotating the map and trying to rebuild certain sections of the castle wall and the lack of hotkeys is fatal in the fast paced matches when trying to vanquish multiple opponents. The voices of the peasants are still provided by the same person, which was fun at frist, in Stronghold HD, but this time it's obviously budget related.Stronghold Crusader HD is obviously a letdown, not mainly because it feels like an expansion, but because it seems like a rather cheap duplicate of the great original. The new setting with all its accessories is a setback and the developer must have also felt the absence of the evil characters of the first game, because in the last mission we can meet them again (don't ask).You might think, "what is this guy talking about, this game isn't that bad" and you might be right, but if you played the original (and you really should have) you'll see how bad it is in comparison.Accordingly I can't recommend Stronghold Crusader HD to anyone: not to newcomers and especially not to fans of the original. If you want to experience a good siege just load up Stronghold HD again. PROS+ some useful additions and readjustments to the game+ last mission is challengingCONS- less emphasis on castle sieges- issues from the original are still present- campaign is not as enjoyable as the one in the original- feels like an expansion rather than a sequel- cheap ways to make the game harderRATING3/10

I remember this game when I was maybe......6?This game really brings back memories with the floppy disk games.Anyway lets review!Note: Buying the game will also include Stronghold Crusader Extreme but that is so terrible so I wont review it.THE GAMEStronghold Crusader HD is a castle sim with I think 4 modes.Career/Story: Really just a set of tutorials and starting battles to get you ready to play the all grand skirmish mode(I think thats what its called) but never the less it can be fun but only sometimes.Skirmish/Battle: This is probably what makes this game grand. It puts you in a screen where you decide things like the map, how many players fight, where they fight, difficulty, starting money, etc. Then you start building a castle and an army to help you crush the other players while not getting recked yourself. THIS IS WHAT YOU GET THE GAME FOR. I bet it would be fun in MP but none of my friends have it :(Castle Builder- Just the mode if you want to build a huge castle, no enemies just you, your people, and that annoying flippin guide. (WHY?)Multiplayer- If someone wants to add me to play this mode please do ;_;AUDIOThe game has solid voice acting from every character and they talk to you at the right times sometimes indicating how you should prepare, like telling you "youre kingdom will get crushed" could indicating that they're lanuching an assault at you. The fighting audio is good but the people getting hit by arrows sounds like there coughing and screaming. Your castle based on how many people actually work it gets more or less chattery and theres less sounds of nature. The only REALLY bad voice acting is your guide, he doesnt change his accent when you change to like a british guy and his voice is just annoying but funny to abuse sometimes. Audio-8/10GAMEPLAYWell as I explained in the modes section you are usually fighting other players, but most of the time youre trying to get people in your kingdom and keep them in your kingdom by maintaning food, taxes, and atractions for your people (like a dancing bear strapped to a pole wtf). Gameplay 9/10STORYLINEI really dont think i should rate this but I will. The game yes has a story mode but it's mostly a tutorial with basic battles. The games story really comes mostly from the gameplay. Think of games like dota 2, CSGO, and TF2 mostly the story comes out of what you do and see, not whats told. Storyline 7/10GraphicsThe graphics would obvioulsy be outdated for a game as old as this but you can see whats going on and not feel like you cant see what that means or indicates. Pretty solid graphics if you look at its age. Im gonna count the score as if I was rating this in the year this was released. Graphics 10/10AI  Since this is what most people have to play with ill make a section for it. As I stated in audio the AI will give you hints about whats about to happen but it might not always happen, making them pretty clever enemies. Each king has a different tactic. By tons I mean like 30 maps each ranging on how many maximum players there can be and I think you are able to get more maps (IDK though). Replayability 10/10VERDICTStronghold Crusader's 10$ price tag is well worth it for such and old and polished game like this.FINAL RATING: 8.6/10

Pros:-Stronghold perfected-In depth economic system-Rebalanced religion and ale mechanics (religion is no longer wildly overpriced for the benefit given)-Multitudes of new units, including arabic units that need only gold, and monks that can be trained at the cathedral-Wide variety of maps and play scenarios-Challenging, fun campaign mode-Computer opponents are widely varied, memorable, and fun to fight-Active online community-Massive replayabilityCons:-No plot; campaign is just premade skirmishes-No fast-forward optionOverall: This is it.  This is the best stronghold game.  Everything after, while sometimes good, failed to measure up.  And Stronghold 1, while perfectly fine, didn't have the added depth this game has.  While this game lacks a proper story mode, it focuses on what there really is to love about this game - the gameplay.  There's a main campaign which consists of 50 skirmish matches against progressively harder scenarios, and another 20 in the "expansion" that comes included with the HD version.There are a multitude of different computer opponents to fight as well, and they can range from comically inept to frighteningly capable.  Maps have a wide range of setups, from the vanilla "everyone starts with the same basic setup and resources" to the maps which have no farmable land, to the maps that give one player every resource and all the others very few at all.  The game is fun, and there are so many different ways to play that it will continue to challenge and entertain you.One of the only real downsides is that there are still times when you watch and wait as your economy chugs along and your opponent builds his army, and there's just nothing for you to do but wait.  Firefly did a good job of reducing that so it isn't as stark and noticeable as it was in Stronghold 1, but it still happens.  A fast forward option would have been nice.  Even more so if you like using swordsmen in sieges - you will legit wait five to ten minutes for them to get from your stronghold to the other guy's stronghold.  Still, this is a very minor complaint in an otherwise flawless game.There's a strong online community creating more maps and scenarios that can be downloaded and played.  The addition of the arabic units with all their unique traits gives Crusader even more depth than before, and really just rounds out an already fantastic game.  This is one of those games I've kept coming back to over the years, and probably will continue to do so for another decade.Bottom Line: Absolute recommend

												This has been a long time coming. SC is one game I have loved from day one. For the first time I played a game that was so complicated it took me a few days to master the economy. I had dreamed of a game like this since I played Warcraft as a small child. A game so realistic you actually had to gather raw materials it was a dream come true. Games have come and gone but SC always remained it was the only game that continued to hold my interest through the years. Even my friends got hooked and my wife who is by no means a gamer. The graphics were subpar even for the time but the gameplay was so entertaining it didn't matter. The attention to detail was beyond compare the concept of citizens you could not control was genius. Every building was bustling with people doing work and sounds of every trade rang out in a crowded village square. I developed many working strategies over the years it was as if there really were no rules. You were limited only by what crazy attack you could think up and how well you executed it. But it wasn't just the gameplay that was exceptional the programming was amazing. The 2D drawing of 3D objects made the game tiny and playable on the oldest computers. I used to carry a copy in my mp3 player so I could play anywhere. It worked on any network without any errors ever seriously in 12 years! I swear this game would run over two tin cans on a string. At some LAN parties we didn't even bother setting up a network we just plugged all the computers into a hub and SC would work even when windows didn't show any other network locations. I still play my original copy and have only encountered a few glitches. I wish they would just remake this game with top of the line graphics. I'll be playing this game till the day I die -SEF

												Stronghold Crusader mixes castle building, RTS, and resource management. The campaign will teach you most of the things from resource gathering, building and defending your castle, to sieging the enemy and defending your castle. Stronghold Crusader has 16 AI lords, each lord has different strategies and difficulties. They also have a different castle builds and troop choices. You can choose to use Arab or European troops or even all together. The extreme edition is a faster paced version of the game that you can play separately from the original game.Stronghold Crusader is one of my favorite RTS games. It is very similar to its predecessor, Stronghold, but it has more content than Stronghold. I first played it since 2007 and bought the steam version recently. It was one of the best and most addicting game I played back then. The game is quite simple when you get the hang of it. The gameplay is still great till this day, even though the game was from 2001. And I really like the HD addition to the game, the max resolution used to be 1024x768 and after the HD addition you can play with almost any resolution. The AI is also quite challenging. The skirmish mode and custom games will add many hours to the game. The soundtrack for Stronghold Crusader is fantastic. I really like the soundtrack of this game. The voice acting is kinda bad, but it really fits with the game somehow. I really like how Arabian units speak Arabic. The integration with Steam Cloud is one of the reasons I bought the Steam version of the game.However, Stronghold Crusader has a minor flaw. The lack of Steam overlay. You can't chat with friends without alt-tabbing and you can't take screenshots via Steam too.In conclusion, even though the game looks outdated, it truly withstood the test of time. Stronghold Crusader is still a very good game and will give hours of fun. I really recommend this game.

												This game is perhaps overlooked by most people these days, considering there are others out there, like StarCraft, Age of Empires, Civilization, and plenty of lesser known RTS games.Yet, this game has a certain charm to it that I think can't be found anywhere else. It's set in the Arabic desert, where you must fight for survival by mastering as many factors as you can, including some staple RTS features, like economics, resources, troops, and workers. This game also features two main ways to determine whether you succeed or not. This comes in the form of managing how much gold you have to buy troops, and how much food you have collected. Running out of food will cause your castle to start losing happiness, and people will begin to leave if it gets below halfway.Since the food plays a major role in your economy, lacking it presents a severe problem of unbalanced gameplay; people won't be able to keep your economy going if they leave, which means that, if you don't have enough gold to buy food, you're basically doomed. You can't buy troops since you don't have gold, and if, by some chance, you happen to be out of other supplies, it's best to give up if you don't have any allies. Even then, the allies aren't guaranteed to help you, especially if they're A.I players.This is where the unbalanced issue comes into place, because not everyone is good at managing their economy, and pitting people with little to no sense of economics against people who do know means that the latter are going to win. Every single time.This is still a great game, though.  If you are willing to learn how to manage economics, I recommend this game.

												Stronghold Crusader, war damals mit eines der Ersten Spiele, die ich sehr aktiv gespielt habe und heute mag ich das Spiel nach wie vor immer noch sehr gerne. Auch wenn die Grafik ein wenig veraltet scheint ist es einfach ein Klassiker und macht auch mit dieser Grafik viel mehr Spaß als die ganzen viel neueren Teilen mit der angeblich besseren Grafik. Das Spiel bietet für jeden etwas. Man kann zum Beispiel, wenn man nicht so auf die aktiven Schlachten steht seine eigene Burg bauen ohne feindliche Angriffe oder ein eigenes Szenario erstellen, welches man an andere Spieler schicken kann, welche sich dann an Eurem Szenario versuchen können. Selbstverständlich bietet dieses Spiel auch zwei Kampagnen durch welche man sich durch kämpfen kann, wobei der Schwierigkeitsgrad immer wieder auf eine höhere Stufe gestellt wird und man lernen muss beispielsweise nur durch den Steinabbau seine Burg finanzieren kann. Außerdem sind auch vier Szenarien aus der Geschichte eingebaut worden, welche auf mehrere kleine Szenarien aufgeteilt wurden.Für Anfänger wird es wahrscheinlich sehr hilfreich sein erstmal schnelle Spiele zu starten, in denen man entscheiden kann inwiefern man einen Vorteil oder Nachteil gegenüber den anderen Spielern beziehungsweise Computer Gegnern erhalten soll.Das Spiel stellt zusätzlich noch eine Möglichkeit bereit im Multiplayer gegeneinander spielen zu können. Hierbei empfiehlt es sich in einem lokalen Netzwerk zu spielen, da man über Hamachi mit vielen Verzögerungen rechnen muss.Insgesamt aber würde ich dieses Spiel jedem empfehlen, der Interesse am Mittelalter hat und auf Strategie- Spiele steht. Für Jemanden, der sich mehr um die Grafik schert, wird dieses Spiel nicht das Beste sein, weil es nun auch schon ein paar Jahre auf den Buckel hat. Sollte dies der Fall sein empfiehlen sich eher Stronghold Crusader 2 oder auch Stronghold 3 oder vielleicht auch Stronghold 2 und Legends.

												Oh, the memories... Lions are attacking,my Liege! Assassins are scaling our walls,Sire! The lions have taken control over our gatehouse,Sire...My friend showed me this gem when we were about 10. Immediately fell in love with the game, cuz medieval stuff. Last year heated this up again to multi-play with friends to celebrate the end of our university years. Still a gem.PRO:+You can build huge castles+You can destroy huge castles (just need a ton of catapults)+Variety in strategy (from destroying castles in seconds with catapults, through picking off defenders one by one with clouds of arrows/darts, to single rushing in with your king because YOLO)+Burn it to the ground! (With flaming arrows and pitch, boiling oil, fire ballistas, torches... and whatever stuff is in those jars Fire Throwers throw.)+Exploit minor bugs against AI+Here comes Bessy!CON:-AI is stupid, games become easy/non-challenging after a while (I may have a few hundred hours of gameplay off-record ;))-no attack move (your units engage enemy only if they run directly into them)-Multiplayer kinda sucks. If you can rush your opponent, it's over too fast, if you can't, it'll never end.-Hidden population limit. I never really figured this out, but it seems to be around a few hundred. I want to conquer the Holy City with my Golden Horde! (gold 'n hoard,eh)...also. Wood needed!
